Management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations is based upon our consolidated financial statements, prepared in accordance with GAAP.
We periodically review long-lived assets for impairment whenever changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable.
Costs related to the development of real estate including initial project acquisition costs, pre-construction costs and construction costs are capitalized.
Useful life ranges for different asset types: Buildings (10-39 years), Tenant Improvements (Shorter of remaining lease term or useful life), Furniture and Fixtures (5-8 years).

The consolidated financial statements include accounts of our subsidiaries which are or were wholly-owned or controlled. Entities we do not control through voting interest, where we are not the primary beneficiary, are accounted for under equity method.
Significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated. Investments in unconsolidated joint ventures are accounted for under equity method.
Management makes estimates affecting reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures at the date of the financial statements.
We operate in one reportable segment, commercial real estate.
Financial instruments exposed to credit risk consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents.
Real estate assets are stated at historical cost, less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
Buildings and improvements: 10 - 39 years, Tenant improvements: shorter of remaining lease term or useful life, Furniture and fixtures: 5 - 8 years.

data.key: Net (loss) income attributable to common stockholders

data.value: December 31, 2019
December 31, 2020
December 31, 2021
December 31, 2022

The company reported net losses for 2021 and 2022, at -$20,805 and -$20,690 respectively, while experiencing a net income of $4,333 in 2020. The net cash from operations improved in 2022 to $1,351 compared to -$65,881 in 2020.
Investing activities showed significant net cash from investing of $17,325 in 2022, an improvement from -$40 in 2021 after a considerable -$662 in 2020.
Financing activities reflected substantial loan proceeds of $30,239 in 2022 and repayments of -$48,415, a notable decrease from $24,9984 in loan proceeds in 2021.
Total cash and equivalents slightly reduced to $22,055 in 2022 from $24,845 in 2021, indicating stability in cash management despite operational challenges.
Leases with tenants are accounted for as operating leases. Minimum rents are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the respective lease.
The excess of rents recognized over amounts contractually due pursuant to the underlying leases are included in deferred rents receivable.
Lease revenues and reimbursement of real estate taxes, insurance and other property operating expenses are presented in the consolidated statements as 'rental revenues.'
We assess the collectability of our accounts receivable related to tenant revenues.
Revenues from the sale of residential condominiums reflects the gross sales price from sales of condominium units recognized at closing.
We account for income taxes under the asset and liability method as required by ASC 740.
Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing net income by the weighted average number of shares.

Our business, operations and financial condition are subject to various risks. Some of these risks are described below, and stockholders should take such risks into account when evaluating us or any investment decision involving us.
We have a limited amount of unrestricted cash and liquidity and variable cash needs.

If we are not successful in consummating a strategic transaction, raising significant additional capital and/or receiving significant amounts on account of our claims involving 237 11th in a timely manner, we will have insufficient cash and liquidity to service our debt and pay operating expenses and other obligations over the next 12 months.
Management is currently in discussions with the Company’s lenders regarding the deferment of upcoming payments and exploring opportunities to secure additional funding.
Evaluating potential alternatives include securing an equity and/or debt financing, refinancing of existing debt, and/or a sale or merger or reverse merger of the Company.
If funds are raised by issuing equity securities, dilution to existing shareholders will result.
We may be required to evaluate additional alternatives in restructuring our business, including filing for bankruptcy protection.
We have limited cash resources, generate minimal revenues from operations, and are reliant on external sources of capital.

elements.title: Risks in Property Development and Investment Returns

data.value: Investment returns from 77 Greenwich and other properties may be less than anticipated.
Sales of condominium units and leasing of properties may yield less profitable returns than projected.
Operating expenses and taxes may exceed projections, affecting profitability.
Inability to secure financing on favorable terms may hinder development.
Construction costs may exceed estimates due to unforeseen factors, impacting profit.
Delays in obtaining necessary permits can inflate costs or halt projects.
Abandonment of development opportunities may result in unrecoverable expenses.
Inability to complete constructions on schedule can result in financial losses.
Economic changes may necessitate suspension of projects, leading to write-offs.

elements.title: Risks Related to Property Acquisitions and Joint Ventures

data.value: We may expend funds on, and devote management time to, opportunities which we do not complete, and which may include non-refundable deposits.
We may be unable to lease our acquired properties on the same terms as contemplated as part of our underwriting.
Properties that we acquire or in which we invest may fail to perform as we expected.
Our estimates of the costs we incur in renovating, improving, developing or redeveloping acquired properties may be inaccurate.
We may not be able to obtain adequate insurance coverage for acquired properties.
We may be unable to quickly and efficiently integrate new acquisitions, investments and developments into our existing operations.
Joint venture investments may involve risks not otherwise present for investments made solely by us.
Changes in LIBOR may affect our financial results and lead to renegotiation of obligations.
Failure to comply with NYC requirements may result in loss of tax benefits.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Common Stock Volatility

data.value: Extreme volatility in fixed income, credit, currency and equity markets could adversely affect business, financial condition and operating results.
Breaches of information technology systems could materially harm business and reputation, including the unauthorized access to sensitive information.
Common stock is thinly traded on the NYSE American, with significant price fluctuations impacting market.
Market price volatility and lack of liquidity may prevent stockholders from selling shares at or above the price paid.
Factors affecting stock price include the ability to raise additional capital, changes in real estate markets, and general economic conditions.
Measured at grant date based on fair value and expensed as per ASC 718-10-35.
Reflect management beliefs and assumptions involving risks and uncertainties.
Existing capital resources may not fund operations for the next 12 months without a strategic transaction or capital raising.
Risks involve debt maturities, defaults, and covenants that may restrict business plans.
Investment may be more costly than anticipated with less favorable returns.
Adverse trends in the New York City residential condominium market.
Ability to enter into new leases and renew existing leases with tenants at commercial and residential properties.
Acquiring properties subject to unknown or known liabilities, limited or no recourse to the seller.
Effects of rent stabilization regulations on ability to raise and collect rents.
Competition for new acquisitions and investments.
Risks associated with acquisitions and investments in owned and leased real estate.
Risks associated with joint ventures.
Ability to maintain state tax benefits for certain properties.
Ability to obtain required permits, site plan approvals, and governmental approvals for property development.
Costs associated with complying with environmental laws and contamination.
Risks related to loss of key personnel.
Effects of new tax laws.
Ability to utilize NOLs to offset future taxable income and capital gains.
Risks associated with current political and economic uncertainty, including outbreaks of contagious diseases.
Risks associated with breaches of information technology systems.
Stock price volatility and other risks associated with lightly traded stock.
Stockholders may be diluted by issuance of additional shares.
A declining stock price may hinder capital raising.
Influence of significant stockholders.
Limitations on transactions in common stock may impact liquidity.
Charter provisions may make takeovers more difficult.
Certain charter provisions may limit stockholder's ability to obtain favorable judicial forums.
Unanticipated difficulties and factors outside our control.

elements.title: Financial Condition and Results of Operations - Liquidity and Capital Resources

data.value: We have not generated an operating profit.
Our long-term viability cannot be assured.
Substantial capital expenditures required.
We face risks generally associated with our debt.
Increased risk of default on obligations.
Several loans have near-term maturities.
Loans require interest rate cap agreements.
May not have funds available to purchase required interest rate cap.
Failure to meet obligations leads to cross-defaults.
Covenants could limit flexibility and adversely affect financial condition.

elements.title: Potential Compliance and Financial Implications of ADA and Economic Uncertainty

data.value: Potential costs and regulatory requirements related to the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Could face fines and damages due to noncompliance with safety regulations.
Potential substantial capital expenditures related to compliance with ADA.
Risks associated with losing key management personnel affecting operations.
Limitations on using net operating losses due to ownership changes and tax legislation.
Potential adverse effects on business due to political or economic changes.
Difficulties in predicting impacts on consumer spending and business operations.
Third Avenue and CCF Lender can exert influence over policies and management.
Threshold of 2,345,000 shares of common stock for director election rights.
No dividends have been paid on common stock and none expected for the foreseeable future.
Charter documents and Delaware law contain provisions to prevent favorable takeovers.
Classified board of directors with two-year staggered terms.
Certificates of incorporation include transfer restrictions affecting liquidity.
Restrictions may affect ability to use NOLs and tax attributes.
Provisions could reduce stock value or discourage investors.

elements.title: Amendment to Corporate Credit Facility and Loan Agreements

data.value: The company defers upcoming interest payments and a $7.0 million amortization payment due on May 1, 2023.
Amendments include allowing entry into the Mezzanine Loan Agreement, reducing commitment under the Corporate Credit Facility from $70.0 million to $62.5 million.
The provision for calculating the MOIC amount combined the CCF and Mezzanine Loan.
Company agrees to prepay outstanding principal balance of CCF no less than $7.0 million by May 1, 2023.
The amount of the CCF used to calculate the MOIC was reduced to $35.75 million.
In November 2022, minimum liquidity requirement was eliminated.
The company issued warrants to purchase up to 7,179,000 shares of common stock.
Exercise price of the Warrants amended from $6.50 per share to $4.31 per share.
As of December 31, 2022, the CCF was fully drawn and compliant with covenants.
Loan agreement extended credit up to $166.7 million with $133.1 million borrowed at closing.
Interest rate set at 7.00% over LIBOR; adjusted rate applicable if balance exceeds $91.0 million.

elements.title: Material Weakness in Internal Control over Financial Reporting

data.value: Identified errors in accounting treatment regarding the overcapitalization of construction costs.
77 Greenwich property reclassified from real estate under development to residential condominium units.
Commenced additional procedures to ensure property classification is correct.
Continued analysis and post-closing procedures until material weakness remediated.

Due to water damage in apartment units and other property at 237 11th resulting from construction defects, a notice of claim was submitted to the insurance carrier. The insurance carrier disclaimed coverage, leading to legal action.
As of December 31, 2022, compliance with covenants of the 237 11th Loans, except for minimum liquidity requirement.
Filed complaints against insurer and contractors to recover damages.
The lender has agreed to waive the minimum liquidity requirement through the initial maturity date of July 9, 2023.
237 11th Loans: $50M senior loan and $10M mezzanine loan; New Berkley Loan: $33M, fixed at 2.717%.
